verses.text: Then all Israel gathered to David at Hebron and said, “Look, we are your own flesh and bone.”
verses.comment: Same as 2 Samuel 5:1. Preserved the idiom 'flesh and bone' for clarity and accuracy.

verses.text: Even earlier, when Saul was king, it was you who led Israel out and brought them in. The Lord your God said to you, ‘You will shepherd my people Israel, and you will be ruler over my people Israel.’
verses.comment: Direct quotation of YHWH cited. Follows original wording.

verses.text: So all the elders of Israel came to the king at Hebron. David made a covenant with them at Hebron before the Lord. And they anointed David king over Israel, as the Lord had spoken through Samuel.
verses.comment: Notes the fulfillment of God’s word spoken by Samuel.

verses.text: David and all Israel went to Jerusalem (that is, Jebus). The Jebusites, who lived there in the land, were there.
verses.comment: Parenthetical note capturing the name Jebus.

verses.text: The people of Jebus said to David, “You will not enter here.” But David captured the stronghold of Zion, which is the city of David.
verses.comment: Maintains terms ‘stronghold of Zion’ and ‘city of David’ for historical/geographical clarity.

verses.text: David said, “Whoever attacks the Jebusites first will be chief and commander.” Joab son of Zeruiah went up first, so he became chief.
verses.comment: Joab’s rise to command noted clearly.

verses.text: David lived in the stronghold; therefore it was called the city of David.
verses.comment: Geographical naming reason maintained.

verses.text: He built the city all around, from the Millo even all the way around, and Joab restored the rest of the city.
verses.comment: The term 'Millo' left untranslated as in original, an unclear fortification.

verses.text: David grew greater and greater, for the Lord of armies was with him.
verses.comment: ‘Lord of armies’ is a literal rendering of ‘Yahweh of hosts’.

verses.text: Now these are the chiefs of David’s mighty men, who with all Israel gave him strong support in his kingdom, to make him king, according to the word of the Lord concerning Israel.
verses.comment: ‘Mighty men’ left as is; ‘word of the Lord’ emphasized for theological accuracy.

verses.text: These are the number of David’s mighty men: Jashobeam son of Hachmoni, the chief of the three. He lifted his spear against three hundred men, whom he killed at one time.
verses.comment: Conforms to original enumeration and naming.

verses.text: And after him was Eleazar son of Dodo, the Ahohite, who was among the three mighty men.
verses.comment: Renders the names as per original Hebrew.

verses.text: He was with David at Pas-dammim when the Philistines were gathered there for battle. There was a plot of ground full of barley, and the people fled from the Philistines.
verses.comment: ‘Pas-dammim’ preserved as ancient location reference.

verses.text: But they took their stand in the midst of the field, defended it, and killed the Philistines. And the Lord saved them with a great victory.
verses.comment: Passive construction swapped for clarity, but meaning unaltered.

verses.text: Three of the thirty chief men went down to the rock to David at the cave of Adullam, while the army of the Philistines was encamped in the Valley of Rephaim.
verses.comment: Notes the ‘rock’ and ‘cave of Adullam’ for geographical context.

verses.text: David was in the stronghold, and the garrison of the Philistines was then at Bethlehem.
verses.comment: ‘Garrison’ retains military connotation.

verses.text: David said with longing, “If only someone would give me water to drink from the well of Bethlehem that is by the gate!”
verses.comment: ‘With longing’ captures the intent of David’s words.

verses.text: So the three broke through the camp of the Philistines, drew water from the well of Bethlehem that was by the gate, and brought it to David. But David would not drink it; he poured it out to the Lord
verses.comment: Action described plainly with David’s refusal explained.

verses.text: and said, “Far be it from me before my God that I should do this. Shall I drink the blood of these men who risked their lives? Because they risked their lives to bring it, I would not drink it.” These things the three mighty men did.
verses.comment: David’s logic preserved, ‘blood’ is metaphorical for their lives.

verses.text: Now Abishai, brother of Joab, was chief of the thirty. He lifted his spear against three hundred men and killed them, and won a name beside the three.
verses.comment: ‘Won a name’ preserves the Hebrew idiom for reputation.

verses.text: He was even more honored than the thirty, and he became their commander; but he did not attain to the three.
verses.comment: ‘He did not attain to the three’ reflects his place in the rankings.

verses.text: And Benaiah son of Jehoiada was a valiant man from Kabzeel, who performed great deeds. He struck down two heroes of Moab. He also went down and killed a lion in a pit on a snowy day.
verses.comment: ‘Heroes of Moab’ may refer to prominent Moabite warriors.

verses.text: He killed an Egyptian, a man of great stature, five cubits tall. The Egyptian had a spear like a weaver’s beam in his hand, but Benaiah went down to him with a staff, snatched the spear from the Egyptian’s hand, and killed him with his own spear.
verses.comment: Preserves size imagery (five cubits ≈ 7.5 feet).

verses.text: These things Benaiah son of Jehoiada did, and won a name among the thirty mighty men.
verses.comment: ‘Won a name’ as per Hebrew idiom for fame.

verses.text: He was more honored than the thirty, but he did not attain to the three. And David set him over his bodyguard.
verses.comment: Maintains logical sequence.

verses.text: The mighty men of the armies were: Asahel the brother of Joab, Elhanan son of Dodo from Bethlehem,
verses.comment: List begins, names as per Hebrew.

verses.text: Shammoth the Harorite, Helez the Pelonite,
verses.comment: The Pelonite can refer to Parathonite in some manuscripts.

verses.text: Ira son of Ikkesh the Tekoite, Abiezer the Anathothite,
verses.comment: Names as per original.

verses.text: Sibbecai the Hushathite, Ilai the Ahohite,
verses.comment: Ilai may be ‘Ittai’ in some texts.

verses.text: Maharai the Netophathite, Heled son of Baanah the Netophathite,
verses.comment: Names as in original.

verses.text: Ithai son of Ribai from Gibeah of the people of Benjamin, Benaiah the Pirathonite,
verses.comment: Clarifies ‘people of Benjamin’ (Benjaminites).

verses.text: Hurai from the brooks of Gaash, Abiel the Arbathite,
verses.comment: Brooks (ravines) of Gaash are kept literal.

verses.text: Azmaveth the Baharumite, Eliahba the Shaalbonite,
verses.comment: Names as per text.

verses.text: the sons of Hashem the Gizonite, Jonathan son of Shagee the Hararite,
verses.comment: Plural ‘sons of Hashem’ retained.

verses.text: Ahiam son of Sachar the Hararite, Eliphal son of Ur,
verses.comment: Ahiam’s parentage specified.

verses.text: Hepher the Mecherathite, Ahijah the Pelonite,
verses.comment: Ahijah may not be in all manuscripts.

verses.text: Hezro the Carmelite, Naarai son of Ezbai,
verses.comment: Kept as literal as possible.

verses.text: Joel the brother of Nathan, Mibhar son of Hagri,
verses.comment: ‘Brother of Nathan’ specified.

verses.text: Zelek the Ammonite, Naharai the Beerothite, the armor-bearer of Joab son of Zeruiah,
verses.comment: Status ‘armor-bearer’ kept for clarity.

verses.text: Ira the Ithrite, Gareb the Ithrite,
verses.comment: Personal names preserved.

verses.text: Uriah the Hittite, Zabad son of Ahlai,
verses.comment: Uriah noted; also named in Bathsheba episode.

verses.text: Adina son of Shiza the Reubenite, a chief of the Reubenites, and thirty with him,
verses.comment: Additional mighty men unique to Chronicles here.

verses.text: Hanan son of Maacah, Joshaphat the Mithnite,
verses.comment: Names as in original.

verses.text: Uzzia the Ashterathite, Shama and Jeiel, sons of Hotham the Aroerite,
verses.comment: Dual sons listed for clarity.

verses.text: Jediael son of Shimri, Joha his brother, the Tizite,
verses.comment: Family relationships specified.

verses.text: Eliel the Mahavite, Jeribai and Joshaviah, sons of Elnaam, Ithmah the Moabite,
verses.comment: Dynastic relationships kept literal.

verses.text: Eliel, Obed, and Jaasiel the Mezobaite.
verses.comment: Final men listed. Names preserved.
